pageProps.contentHtml:
entire functions

For an entire function f(z)=f(0)(z)f\p{z} = f^{\p{0}}\p{z}f(z)=f(0)(z), we define

f(n)(z)=f(f(n−1)(z))for all n≥1.f^{\p{n}}\p{z} = f\p{f^{\p{n-1}}\p{z}} \quad\text{for all } n \geq 1.f(n)(z)=f(f(n−1)(z))for all n≥1.
  1. Show that if there exists an n≥1n \geq 1n≥1 such that f(n)f^{\p{n}}f(n) is a polynomial, then fff is a polynomial.
  2. Prove that for any n>1n > 1n>1 we have f(n)(z)≠ezf^{\p{n}}\p{z} \neq e^zf(n)(z)=ez.
Solution.

  1. Suppose otherwise, and let nnn be minimal, i.e., f(n)f^{\p{n}}f(n) is polynomial but f(n−1)f^{\p{n-1}}f(n−1) is not. Then f(n−1)f^{\p{n-1}}f(n−1) has an essential singularity at ∞\infty∞, so by Casorati-Weierstrass, there exists a sequence {zk}k\set{z_k}_k{zk​}k​ such that zk→∞z_k \to \inftyzk​→∞ and f(n−1)(zk)→z0∈Cf^{\p{n-1}}\p{z_k} \to z_0 \in \Cf(n−1)(zk​)→z0​∈C. But by continuity,

    f(n)(zk)=f(f(n−1)(zk))→k→∞f(z0)≠∞,f^{\p{n}}\p{z_k} = f\p{f^{\p{n-1}}\p{z_k}} \xrightarrow{k\to\infty} f\p{z_0} \neq \infty,f(n)(zk​)=f(f(n−1)(zk​))k→∞​f(z0​)=∞,

    but this contradicts the fact that polynomials have a pole at ∞\infty∞. Thus, no nnn could have existed to begin with.

  2. Suppose otherwise, so that f(n)(z)=ezf^{\p{n}}\p{z} = e^zf(n)(z)=ez. Then

    f(ez)=f(f(n)(z))=f(n)(f(z))=ef(z).f\p{e^z} = f\p{f^{\p{n}}\p{z}} = f^{\p{n}}\p{f\p{z}} = e^{f\p{z}}.f(ez)=f(f(n)(z))=f(n)(f(z))=ef(z).

    Thus, if g(z)=f(ez)=ef(z)g\p{z} = f\p{e^z} = e^{f\p{z}}g(z)=f(ez)=ef(z), then we see that ggg must omit 000, since ef(z)≠0e^{f\p{z}} \neq 0ef(z)=0 for any zzz. Similarly, since ez≠0e^z \neq 0ez=0, we also see that ggg omits f(0)f\p{0}f(0). Since fff is non-constant, little Picard implies that f(0)=0f\p{0} = 0f(0)=0. But this means

    1=e0=f(n)(0)=0,1 = e^0 = f^{\p{n}}\p{0} = 0,1=e0=f(n)(0)=0,

    a contradiction. Thus, no nnn could have existed to begin with.
